Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Small: Integrated modeling and manufacturing framework for soft fluidic robotics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to leverage recent advances in 3D-printing technology and in the robotics communities: open-source tools to enable rapid, on-site design and manufacture of soft, human-friendly robots. These soft robots can be customized to the geometry of a particular task by creating 3D molds from the object geometry where embedded chambers for fluid can be molded into the elastomer. Actuation of the devices can be achieved by pressurizing the chambers, leading to induced strain in certain parts of the elastomeric material. The research will enable 3D simulations of soft robot designs to be performed via a finite element approach that takes into account the complex geometry and non-linear material properties. Deliverables include a catalog of design and fabrication rules for soft robots, guidelines for simulating fluid-structure interaction with finite element modeling, demonstration and validation via hardware, documentation of research results, engineering student education, and the development of an open-source platform for sharing the research with the broader educational and research communities.

If successful, the results of this research will provide an opportunity to create custom soft robots that are inherently low-cost and safe for interacting with humans and fragile objects. This will lead the way for a transition from conventional machines to a new generation of versatile, multifunctional soft systems customized for specification applications where safe interaction with humans and the environment is critical. Example applications include soft robotic braces that can be customized for patients for physical rehabilitation and soft robotic grippers for that can be customized to particular objects on manufacturing assembly lines. For dissemination, an open-source platform will be developed that will consist of 3D CAD models, simulation files, fabrication instructions that can all be adapted for other applications. This information will enable high-school students, undergraduate design teams, and academic and industrial researchers to create their own soft robots.

Institution.Name: Harvard University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research has contributed to the development of hardware and software tools to enable customized fluidic-based soft robots to be rapidly designed and fabricated for a variety of applications including soft wearable robots, soft robotic graspers and insect-inspired robots. In addition, materials from this research have been shared via an open-source approach and helped to create an online community resource for soft robotics researchers. These soft robots can be created from inexpensive components and can be customized for performing a particular task by creating soft robotic devices with customized geometry. Actuation of the devices is achieved by pressurizing embedded chambers, leading to induced strain in certain parts of the elastomeric and textile materials.

 

A key research outcome has been designing and modeling tools for simulating fluid-interaction with soft robot designs with complex geometry and non-linear material properties. This enables design concepts to be rapidly iterated, force-displacement characteristics to be predicted and complex motions and interaction with objects to be better understood. The design tools have immense potential to streamline and accelerate the design of soft actuators for a particular task, eliminating much of the trial and error procedure that is currently used. To demonstrate the potential of this approach, actuators were designed to replicate the motion of the index finger and thumb, motivated by the need to design actuators for use in an assistive glove.

 

The results of this research will provide an opportunity to create custom soft robots that are inherently low-cost and safe for interacting with humans and fragile objects. This will lead the way for a transition from conventional machines to a new generation of versatile, multifunctional soft systems customized for specification applications where safe interaction with humans and the environment is critical.  Example demonstrations from this research include soft wearable robots that can be customized to patients for physical rehabilitation, soft robotic grippers and multi-legged soft robotic platforms.

 

For dissemination, an open-source platform called The Soft Robotics Toolkit was launched as part of this research project. Since its launch in September 2014, the toolkit website has had 2,000,000+ page views, users from 195 countries, 245,000+ users, 29,000 downloads and now has 370 average visits per day. In addition to creating the online site to disseminate soft robotic materials, these materials have also been used as part of outreach activities such as public lectures and workshops. This information has proved valuable in enabling high-school students, undergraduate design teams, and academic and industrial researchers to learn about this field and create their own soft robots.

These soft robots can be created from inexpensive components and can be customized for performing a particular task by creating soft robotic devices with customized geometry. This enables design concepts to be rapidly iterated, force-displacement characteristics to be predicted and complex motions and interaction with objects to be better understood. The design tools have immense potential to streamline and accelerate the design of soft actuators for a particular task, eliminating much of the trial and error procedure that is currently used. To demonstrate the potential of this approach, actuators were designed to replicate the motion of the index finger and thumb, motivated by the need to design actuators for use in an assistive glove. The results of this research will provide an opportunity to create custom soft robots that are inherently low-cost and safe for interacting with humans and fragile objects. This will lead the way for a transition from conventional machines to a new generation of versatile, multifunctional soft systems customized for specification applications where safe interaction with humans and the environment is critical. This information has proved valuable in enabling high-school students, undergraduate design teams, and academic and industrial researchers to learn about this field and create their own soft robots.
